topic.name: Videography, Film & Audio Production
topic.sub_subject_name: Art History, Aesthetic Philosophy & Christian Worldview
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Videography, Film & Audio Production in Fine Arts

objectives.objective_text: Identify wind noise.
Identify a boom mic.
Identify moving the camera vs. keeping it still.
Name zooming in.
Identify focus.
Identify if a video is too dark.
Identify skin tones.
Identify a transition (fade).
Identify that videos can make people happy or sad.
Identify bullying in media.
Identify the main character.
Recall that we listen with our ears.
Observe that shaky video is hard to watch.
Observe colors on TV.
Recall that God sees what we watch.
Recall that movies are planned.
Draw three boxes: Beginning, Middle, End.
Be quiet on the set.
Speak loud enough for the iPad/Camera.
Summarize why the built-in mic is not great.
Explain clapping to sync audio and video.
Avoid recording near a noisy fridge or AC.
Explain room tone.
Defend the adage 'Audio is 50% of the video'.
Hold the camera horizontal (landscape).
Summarize Pan (side to side) and Tilt (up and down).
Explain the Establishing Shot.
Explain the tracking shot.
Defend lighting and composition choices.
Make a video look old (sepia).
Make a video look cold (blue).
Summarize White Balance (orange vs. blue light).
Explain why we fix color.
Explain dynamic range.
Defend the emotional weight of color palettes.
Put video clips in order.
Cut off the boring start and end.
Watch the movie.
Summarize the timeline view.
Add a title card.
Explain 'Jump Cut'.
Add music to the background.
Explain the montage.
Defend the 'invisible edit' vs. stylistic disruption.
Make a video that is kind.
Share good news.
Summarize the purpose of the video (teach, entertain, inspire).
Explain who the audience is.
Explain the responsibility of the creator.
Defend a Christian aesthetic in a secular industry.
Tell the story out loud.
Summarize a scene in comic strip form.
Write dialogue for two characters.
Explain a 'Shot' (one piece of video).
Plan a location for filming.
Explain the 'Beat Sheet'.
Defend the necessity of pre-production.
Analyze the pickup pattern of a shotgun mic.
Interpret audio levels (green, yellow, red/peaking).
Connect lavalier mics to interviews.
Compare a high angle (looking down) vs. low angle.
Analyze the Rule of 180 (spatial continuity).
Interpret the emotional effect of a dolly zoom (vertigo effect).
Connect rack focus to directing attention.
Compare a raw video with a filtered one.
Analyze Color Correction (fixing) vs. Grading (style).
Interpret the Teal and Orange look.
Connect saturation to mood.
Analyze the J-cut and L-cut (audio/video offset).
Interpret pacing (fast cuts vs. long takes).
Connect continuity editing to realism.
Analyze the worldview of a film.
Interpret media bias.
Connect storytelling to the parables of Jesus.
Analyze Shot Types (Close Up, Wide, Medium).
Interpret screenplay formatting (Scene Heading, Action, Dialogue).
Connect the storyboard to the final edit.
Evaluate signal-to-noise ratio.
Evaluate the use of lens compression.
Evaluate vectorscopes for skin tone accuracy.
Evaluate the rhythm of the edit.
Evaluate the cultural impact of media trends.
Evaluate the visual narrative structure.
Construct a double-system sound recording.
Synthesize dialogue editing with foley and score.
Construct a cinematic sequence with motivated camera movement.
Synthesize technical camera operation with storytelling.
Construct a grade using LUTs and curves.
Synthesize visual consistency across shots.
Construct a narrative edit with complex layering.
Synthesize color grading and sound mixing in the NLE.
Create a message that helps someone.
Construct a redemptive narrative.
Synthesize technical excellence with truth-telling.
Construct a shooting script and shot list.
Synthesize visual planning with logistical scheduling.
